channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: Pakistan: U.S. Drone Strike Kills 4
item.description: Four people were killed in northwestern Pakistan in an American drone attack on a vehicle, government and tribal administration officials said Friday.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By ISMAIL KHAN

item.title: World Briefing | Africa: Central African Republic: Rebels Head to Capital After Seizing Town
item.description: Rebels in the Central African Republic have advanced to within “a few kilometers” of the capital, Bangui, a spokesman for France’s Foreign Ministry said Friday.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Kurish Leader Declares Truce With Turkey
item.description: The jailed Kurdish rebel leader Abdullah Ocalan on Thursday called for a cease-fire and ordered all his fighters off Turkish soil, in a landmark moment for a newly energized effort to end three decades of armed conflict with the Turkish government.
item.dc:creator: By SEBNEM ARSU
item.media:description: Flags bore the image of the Kurdish leader Abdullah Ocalan at a rally in Diyarbakir on Thursday.

item.title: Lebanese Prime Minister Resigns as Sectarian Tensions Rise
item.description: Najib Mikati resigned on Friday and called for a unity government to rescue Lebanon from deepening divisions over the war in Syria, which threatens to spill over the border.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD
item.media:description: Prime Minister Najib Mikati, center, in Beirut on Friday. His cabinet had refused to extend the tenure of the police chief.

item.title: At Yad Vashem in Israel, Obama Urges Action Against Racism
item.description: Israel’s apology for errors in a 2010 raid on a ship bound for Gaza thawed relations with Turkey and gave President Obama a solid achievement as he closed out his Middle East visit.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN and MARK LANDLER
item.media:description: President Obama with President Shimon Peres, left, and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu in Jerusalem on Friday.

item.title: World Briefing | Middle East: Egypt: Dozens Injured in Protests
item.description: Dozens of people were injured Friday when thousands of supporters and opponents of the ruling Muslim Brotherhood clashed outside the group’s Cairo headquarters.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By KAREEM FAHIM

item.title: Brazilian Police Storm Indigenous Squatters at Maracanã
item.description: At the home of the 2014 World Cup and 2016 Olympics, the clash highlighted tension over evictions in areas scheduled for development.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By SIMON ROMERO and TAYLOR BARNES
item.media:description: A standoff in an effort to dislodge indigenous people living in Rio de Janeiro’s former Indian Museum highlighted tensions over evictions for development for two major sporting events.

item.title: Toll Rises as Sectarian Violence in Myanmar Spreads
item.description: At least 20 people have died in clashes between Buddhists and Muslims outside a city in central Myanmar, according to residents, a member of Parliament and local journalists.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER
item.media:description: Firemen try to extinguish a fire after mobs of Buddhists ransacked and burned Muslim neighborhoods since Wednesday.

item.title: Italy’s President Asks Democratic Party to Form a Government
item.description: President Giorgio Napolitano of Italy has asked the center-left Democratic Party to try to form a government, but political analysts predict that will be difficult.
item.dc:creator: By RACHEL DONADIO

item.title: The Lede: Pope Cancels Newspaper Delivery Back Home in Argentina
item.description: “Seriously, it’s Jorge Bergoglio, I’m calling you from Rome,” the new pope insisted in a call to Buenos Aires.
item.dc:creator: By RAVI SOMAIYA

item.title: Musharraf, Ex-President of Pakistan, to End Exile
item.description: In an effort to aid his fledgling political party, Pervez Musharraf said he would return on Sunday to Pakistan, where he faces stiff opposition and criminal charges.
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.dc:creator: By DECLAN WALSH
item.media:description: A man stood guard in Thursday in Karachi, Pakistan, at the campaign office of Pervez Musharraf. Security on his return is a critical concern.

item.title: As Cyprus Crisis Deepens, Wealthy Russians Are Ensnared
item.description: About 25 percent of Russian foreign direct investment moves through Cyprus, according to an estimate, often in a way meant to lubricate Russia’s economy.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:description: Dmitry Rybolovlev, worth an estimated $9.1 billion, has sheltered much of his fortune in Cyprus.

item.title: The Lede: Interview With Cuban Blogger Yoani Sánchez
item.description: Yoani Sánchez, a Cuban dissident, is on an 80-day international tour after the Cuban government allowed her to leave the country for the first time in a decade.
item.dc:creator: By NATALIE KITROEFF

item.title: Cyprus’s Bailout Plan Meets With Skepticism
item.description: Lawmakers put off voting on a key new proposal that would confiscate 22 percent to 25 percent of uninsured deposits over 100,000 euros in one of Cyprus’s most troubled banks.
item.dc:creator: By LIZ ALDERMAN
item.media:description: Cypriot’s Parliament passed measures to reshape the banking sector, but delayed a vote on a new tax for uninsured deposits.

item.title: The Lede: Arab Student Explains Why He Heckled Obama in Jerusalem
item.description: The 24-year-old Arab-Israeli student who interrupted President Obama’s speech in Jerusalem on Thursday explained his comments and why he said them in an interview on Friday.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY
item.media:description: Rabbea Eid, an Arab-Israeli student, was removed by security after interrupting President Obama's speech in Jerusalem on Thursday.

item.title: Chinua Achebe, Nigerian Writer, Dies at 82
item.description: Mr. Achebe, the celebrated author of “Things Fall Apart,” wrote stirring essays and poignant poems rooted in his native Nigeria’s cities and countryside.
item.dc:creator: By JONATHAN KANDELL
item.media:description: Chinua Achebe, a Nigerian-born novelist and poet, on the campus of Bard College in Annandale-on-Hudson, N.Y., in 2008.

item.title: Lebanon’s Prime Minister Resigns
item.description: Najib Mikati’s departure threatens to leave a void in Lebanon’s highest ranks at a time of rising tensions and sporadic violence inflamed by the civil war in Syria.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Egyptian Women Take on Sexual Assault Problem
item.description: The increase in attacks against women has illustrated a continuing hostility toward politically active women.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By MAYY EL SHEIKH and DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK
item.media:description: Women in Cairo's Tahrir Square protested on the second anniversary of the revolution on Jan. 25.

item.title: At War Blog: Waiting for War, and Working to Fit In
item.description: A general assignment reporter from Manhattan, Michael Wilson worked hard to fit in among the Marine officers in Kuwait and Iraq.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL WILSON

item.title: War Crimes Suspect, Bosco Ntaganda, Leaves Congo for The Hague
item.description: Bosco Ntaganda, a rebel commander accused of massacring Congolese civilians, was flown out of Rwanda bound for the International Criminal Court at The Hague.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By JEFFREY GETTLEMAN

item.title: The Lede: Serbs and Croats Renew Soccer Hostilities
item.description: A World Cup qualifying match on Friday between the Croatian and Serbian national soccer teams carries the weight of the ethnic tension of the 1990s.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY
item.media:description: Supporters of Croatia's national soccer team in Zagreb on Friday.

item.title: Sarkozy Pushes Back Against Campaign-Finance Inquiry
item.description: Former President Nicolas Sarkozy is accused of abusing the frailty of France’s richest woman to get money for a campaign.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER and SCOTT SAYARE
item.media:description: Former President Nicolas Sarkozy in April 2012.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: What Are You Doing for World Water Day?
item.description: Friday is World Water Day, dedicated to promoting access to clean water, a challenge that is only growing as population and pollution increase.
item.dc:creator: By CHRISTOPHER F. SCHUETZE
item.media:description: A farmer carries water to irrigate his cucumber plants in India.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Russia Resists Savior Role in Cyprus
item.description: There might be benefits for Moscow in rescuing Cyprus from the financial demands coming from its European Union partners. On Friday, however, it sent home a Cypriot envoy empty-handed.
item.dc:creator: By HARVEY MORRIS
item.media:description: Shop owners in Nicosia discussed the crisis on Friday.

item.title: Obama Tries to Charm Israelis With Hebrew
item.description: President Obama sprinkled Hebrew throughout his public remarks during his trip to Israel, an element of his effort to connect with the Israeli public.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN
